props.name: groupContentWithHeader
props.docs:
Specifies wether accordion-panel components should group the content with header in one card
if true, there will be only one card with the header and the content
Nothing change when the panel is close

props.name: hideActionText
props.docs:
Specifies whether accordion-panel components should display the open/close text.
if false, it won't show the open/close text in all accordion-panel.

props.name: highlight
props.docs:
Specifies whether accordion-panel components should highlight when open with primary color.
if true, the background color of the accordion-panel will be the primary color.
if false, the background color of the accordion-panel will be wcs-light.

props.name: groupContentWithHeader
props.docs:
Specifies wether the component should group the content with header in one card
if true, there will be only one card with the header and the content
Nothing change when the panel is close

props.name: hideActionText
props.docs:
Specifies whether the component should display the open/close text.
if false, it won't show the open/close text.

props.name: highlight
props.docs:
Specifies whether the component should highlight when open with primary color.
if true, the background color will be the primary color.
if false, the background color will be wcs-light.

components.docs:
Button component, can also be a link when specifying href.

## Click event

The WCS button relies on the native click event to pass a user click to your app.
For now, it's not possible for us to prevent the click event to be fired when the button's disabled attribute is true.
This means you'll receive click events on a disabled wcs button.
If you're using the button with a library like Angular or React, they have internal mechanisms to prevent this behavior. Your callbacks will therefore not be called.
To fix this problem, we plan to provide a wcsClick event in addition to the native click for applications developed without frameworks.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Specify whether the button is disabled or not.

props.name: href
props.docs:
Set a URL to point to.
If specified use a `a` tag instead of `btn`.

props.name: loading
props.docs: Flag to display spinner until the end of action

props.name: mode
props.docs: This attribute specify the appearance of the button.

props.docs: Specify whether the button should have a ripple effect or not.

props.name: shape
props.docs: Specify the shape of the button.

props.name: size
props.docs: Specify the size of the button.

props.name: target
props.docs:
Specifies where to open the linked document when using href (see prop above)
Default '_self' will open the linked document in the same frame as it was clicked

props.docs: Specify the button type.

props.docs: If `true`, the checkbox is selected.

props.docs: Specify wether the checkbox is disabled or not.

props.docs: If `true` the checkbox is in indeterminate state.

props.name: labelAlignment
props.docs: Specifie the alignment of the checkbox with the label content

events.docs: Emitted when the checked property has changed.

components.docs:
Counter component, meant to be used for small range of values (e.g : 0 - 5).
For larger or specific ranges, please use [wcs-input (type number)](.?path=/docs/components-input--documentation)

props.docs: Specify whether the counter is disabled or not.

props.docs:
The label of the counter.
e.g. Number of passengers, train carriages, railroad tracks...

props.name: max
props.docs:
The maximum value of the counter.
If the value of the max attribute isn't set, then the element has no maximum value.

props.name: min
props.docs:
The minimum value of the counter.
If the value of the min attribute isn't set, then the element has no minimum value.

props.docs: Specify the size (height) of the counter.

props.name: step
props.docs: Defines by how much the counter will be incremented or decremented.

props.name: value
props.docs: The current value of the counter.

events.docs: Emitted when the counter loses focus.
Emitted when the value of the counter has changed.

components.docs:
The editable-field component can be used to simplify the user experience, avoiding the use of a redirection to a form
to edit the data of an entity. You can use it with these wrapped components : `wcs-input`, `wcs-textarea`, `wcs-select`. 

This component is not present in the SNCF design system specifications, so we tried to build it in the most
"discoverable" way possible (for users who interact with), but it's a first version.

**How to use **  
This component is mostly used with a server that returns a response to the input sent through the `wcsChange` event.
It has 3 internal states :
- DISPLAY = the default state of the editable-field
- EDIT = the editable-field is editable, the user should input the data
- LOADING = the data is submitted and the editable-field is waiting for a **response**

A **response** is needed to get the component out of the LOADING state. You can either :
- Set the `value` property to a different value to tell the component to refresh and go back into DISPLAY state
- Use the `successHandler` callback through the `wcsChange` event (see interface [EditableComponentUpdateEvent](https://gitlab.com/SNCF/wcs/-/blob/develop/src/components/editable-field/editable-field-interface.tsx))
- Use the `errorHandler` callback through the `wcsChange` event (see interface [EditableComponentUpdateEvent](https://gitlab.com/SNCF/wcs/-/blob/develop/src/components/editable-field/editable-field-interface.tsx))

props.name: errorMsg

props.docs: Initial value of the field

events.docs: Event called at each (valid) update of the field.

components.docs:
The `wcs-error` should always be wrapped in a `wcs-form-field`.
It is used to display a red message under the field indicating an incorrect user input.

## Accessibility guidelines 
- Provide a relevant error message to inform the users what they should change to make the field valid
- `aria-description` will be automatically added to the field for screen readers
- `aria-invalid="true"` will be automatically added to the field for screen readers

components.docs:
Form field component wraps the native input element and add some more functionality on top of it.

You can use the `wcs-form-field` to wrap any of these components :
- `wcs-input`
- `wcs-textarea`
- `wcs-radio-group`
- `wcs-switch`
- `wcs-checkbox`
- `wcs-native-select`
- `wcs-select`
- `wcs-counter`

For non-supported slotted component, you can use the `required` attribute on the wrapped component to tell the
form-field that it is required. It will add a red star after the label of the form field.

## Accessibility guidelines 
- Each form control should be identified with a unique `wcs-label`
- Don't forget to add form validation to make sure the data is correctly formatted
- If the `wcs-label` is required, the form control must have the `required` HTML attribute and vice-versa (this is normally automatically set)
- The form should not be submittable if at least one required form control is not filled
- Hints are optional and should only be used to add extra information

components.docs: The grid pagination is a subcomponent of `wcs-grid`, slotted in `grid-pagination` under the `<table>` element.

props.name: availablePageSizes
props.docs: Set the available page sizes in the pagination dropdown on the left.

props.name: currentPage
props.docs: The current page of the pagination. First page starts at index 0.

props.name: itemsCount
props.docs:
Total elements in the grid.  
- **Grid in `Server mode`** : You have to set `itemsCount` = your total data length.  
- **Grid not in Server mode** : Do not set it manually : itemsCount is set and updated every pagination refresh.

props.name: pageCount
props.docs:
Max number of pages.  
- **Grid in `Server mode`** : You have to set `pageCount` = `itemsCount` divided by `pageSize`.  
- **Grid not in Server mode** : Do not set it manually : pageCount is set and updated every pagination refresh.

props.name: pageSize
props.docs:
Maximum number of elements shown per page.  
Default is the first value of `availablePageSizes`.

events.docs: Event emitted when the pagination changes.

components.docs:
The `wcs-hint` should always be wrapped in a `wcs-form-field`.
It is used to display an informative message under the field indicating an incorrect user input.

## Accessibility guidelines 
- Provide a relevant hint message to inform the users about the format, how the data should be filled in, or what is the purpose of the field
- `aria-description` will be automatically added to the field for screen readers

props.name: small
props.docs: Whether the component should display the small version of the hint

props.name: checkOnComplete
props.docs: Specifies whether a check should be displayed when a step is passed.

props.name: currentStep
props.docs: index of the active step. The index corresponds to the index of the step in the 'steps' list

props.name: mode
props.docs:
Specifies if the stepper is in linear mode (the user can only click on the next step)
or non-linear (the user can click on any step)

props.name: steps
props.docs: steps to display

events.docs: Emits when the user selects a new step.

components.docs:
The input component is a form control that accepts a single line of text.
Implementation mainly inspired from Ionic Input Component.


<details>
    <summary>Accessibility guidelines </summary>
    > - Provide a `<wcs-label>` next to the input
    > - Use the `disabled` prop to add the HTML `disabled` attribute to the `input`
    > - Use the `readonly` prop to add the HTML `readonly` attribute to the `input`
    > - Use the `autofocus` prop to add the HTML `autofocus` attribute to the `input`. Use it if you want your input focus
    automatically when the page load
    > - Adapt the `type` to lets user enter information more easily (_ex: `type="number"` for an input which only accept numbers entry_)
</details>

props.name: accept
props.docs:
If the value of the type attribute is `"file"`, then this attribute will indicate the types of files that the
server accepts, otherwise it will be ignored. The value must be a comma-separated list of unique content type specifiers.

props.name: autocapitalize
props.docs:
Indicates whether and how the text value should be automatically capitalized as it is entered/edited by the user.
Available options: `"off"`, `"none"`, `"on"`, `"sentences"`, `"words"`, `"characters"`.

props.name: autocomplete
props.docs: Indicates whether the value of the control can be automatically completed by the browser.

props.name: autocorrect
props.docs: Whether auto correction should be enabled when the user is entering/editing the text value.

props.name: autofocus
props.docs: This Boolean attribute lets you specify that a form control should have input focus when the page loads.

props.name: clearInput
props.docs: If `true`, a clear icon will appear in the input when there is a value. Clicking it clears the input.

props.name: clearOnEdit
props.docs:
If `true`, the value will be cleared after focus upon edit.
Defaults to `true` when `type` is `"password"`, `false` for all other types.

props.name: debounce
props.docs:
Set the amount of time, in milliseconds, to wait to trigger the `wcsInput` event after each keystroke.
This also impacts form bindings such as `ngModel` or `v-model`.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the input.

props.name: enterkeyhint
props.docs:
A hint to the browser for which enter key to display.
Possible values: `"enter"`, `"done"`, `"go"`, `"next"`,
`"previous"`, `"search"`, and `"send"`.

props.name: icon
props.docs: Name of the material icon to add to the input

props.name: inputmode
props.docs:
A hint to the browser for which keyboard to display.
Possible values: `"none"`, `"text"`, `"tel"`, `"url"`,
`"email"`, `"numeric"`, `"decimal"`, and `"search"`.

props.name: max
props.docs: The maximum value, which must not be less than its minimum (min attribute) value.

props.name: maxlength
props.docs:
If the value of the type attribute is `text`, `email`, `search`, `password`, `tel`, or `url`, this attribute
specifies the maximum number of characters that the user can enter.

props.name: min
props.docs: The minimum value, which must not be greater than its maximum (max attribute) value.

props.name: minlength
props.docs:
If the value of the type attribute is `text`, `email`, `search`, `password`, `tel`, or `url`, this attribute
specifies the minimum number of characters that the user can enter.

props.name: multiple
props.docs:
If `true`, the user can enter more than one value. This attribute applies when the type attribute is set to
`"email"` or `"file"`, otherwise it is ignored.

props.name: name
props.docs: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

props.name: pattern
props.docs:
A regular expression that the value is checked against. The pattern must match the entire value, not just some
subset. Use the title attribute to describe the pattern to help the user. This attribute applies when the value
of the type attribute is `"text"`, `"search"`, `"tel"`, `"url"`, `"email"`, `"date"`, or `"password"`, otherwise
it is ignored. When the type attribute is `"date"`, `pattern` will only be used in browsers that do not support
the `"date"` input type natively. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/input/date for
more information.

props.name: placeholder
props.docs: Instructional text that shows before the input has a value.

props.name: prefixLabel
props.docs: Prefix displayed before the text field contents. This is not included in the value.

props.name: readonly
props.docs: If `true`, the user cannot modify the value.

props.name: required
props.docs: If `true`, the user must fill in a value before submitting a form.

props.name: size
props.docs: Specify the size (height) of the input.

props.name: spellcheck
props.docs: If `true`, the element will have its spelling and grammar checked.

props.name: state
props.docs:
Specifies the state of the input. By default the input is in an normal state but you can to set it to 'error'
state if the data given by the user is not valid.

props.name: step
props.docs:
Works with the min and max attributes to limit the increments at which a value can be set.
Possible values are: `"any"` or a positive floating point number.

props.name: suffixLabel
props.docs: Suffix displayed after the text field contents. This is not included in the value.

props.name: type
props.docs: The type of control to display. The default type is text.

props.name: value
props.docs: The value of the input.

methods.name: getInputElement
methods.docs: Returns the native `<input>` element used under the hood.

methods.name: setFocus

docsTags.name: deprecated
docsTags.text:
use the native focus method instead
Sets focus on the native `input` in `wcs-input`.

methods.deprecation:
use the native focus method instead
Sets focus on the native `input` in `wcs-input`.

events.docs: Emitted when the input loses focus.
Emitted when the value has changed. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/change
Emitted when the input has focus.
Emitted when a keyboard input occurred. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/input

components.docs:
The `wcs-label` should always be wrapped in a `wcs-form-field`.
It is used to caption a form control component.

## Accessibility guidelines 
- Use concise name for the label. If you want to describe more your form control, add a `wcs-hint`
- Use the required flag only as an indication to inform users that the form control is required

props.name: required
props.docs:
If `true`, marks the label with a red star.
Automatically added if the wrapped component inside the `wcs-form-field` already has the `required` attribute.

props.name: activated
props.docs: True if the item is active. Adds a background color that highlights it.

props.name: family
props.docs: Family of the icon

props.name: icon
props.docs: Use the icon name from Material Icons

props.name: size
props.docs: Size of the icon

# Modal ## Modal without backdrop ```html
Modal title
Voulez-vous quittez la page ?
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis a cursus mi. Nullam et sem mi. Interdum et malesuada fames ac ante ipsum primis in faucibus. Fusce sollicitudin pellentesque libero nec elementum.
C'est non J'accepte
``` Afficher la bote de dialogue
components.docs:
The modal component (also named dialog or popup) is an interface element that appears on top of the page content.
Use it to show a message, a confirmation dialog, or any other content like forms.

<details>
    <summary>Accessibility guidelines </summary>
    > - Modal element has `role="dialog"` and `aria-modal="true"`
    > - Keyboard navigation is trapped inside the modal
    > - It is mandatory to set the `modal-trigger-controls-id` to the id of the element that opens the dialog, in order
    > to focus it upon dialog dismissal.
    > - The modal can be closed at any time by pressing the Escape key.
    >
    > - More info : https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/dialog-modal/
</details>

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-modal-max-height - Max height of the main container

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-modal-overflow-y - Overflow-y of the content

docsTags.name: slot
docsTags.text: <no-name> Main container slot

docsTags.name: slot
docsTags.text: header Header container slot (for title)

docsTags.name: slot
docsTags.text: actions Actions container slot (for buttons)

props.name: hideActions
props.docs: Specifies whether the component should hide the actions slot or not

props.name: modalTriggerControlsId
props.docs: Specifies which element id controls the modal

props.name: show
props.docs: Displays the modal

props.name: showCloseButton
props.docs:
Specifies whether the component should display a close button.
if false, it won't close the modal when the escape key is pressed.

props.name: size
props.docs:
There are multiple sizes for modals. The default size is medium (m), however other sizes are available. Select the
size best suited for the content and screen size displaying the modal. Remember to test responsiveness.

props.name: withoutBackdrop
props.docs: Specifies whether the component should display a backdrop on the entire page

events.docs: Triggered when the user leaves the dialog with the closing button.

components.docs:
The `wcs-native-select` component is designed to accept a native `<select>` element as a slotted child. This choice
allows developers to bind the `<select>` element using the framework of their choice, without the need to re-expose all the
properties of the `<select>` and `<option>` elements in this component.

The component wraps the native `<select>` element and provides custom styles and behavior, while preserving the native
functionality and accessibility.

###  Guidance

- To have a placeholder, you must have an option as child which has `selected` attribute and `disabled`
attribute. You can add the `hidden` attribute to don't show the placeholder option in the options overlay.

### Example usage

```html
<wcs-native-select>
  <select>
    <option value="option1">Option 1</option>
    <option value="option2">Option 2</option>
    <option value="option3">Option 3</option>
  </select>
</wcs-native-select>
```

### Note
- We did not find a way to detect when the select is reset, if you want to apply the placeholder style when the
select is reset, you have to call the `updateStyles()` method manually.
- It is strongly recommended to use select-native when you don't have to support the multi-selection feature

props.name: size
props.docs:
The `size` property controls the size of the slotted `select` element by adjusting its padding.
There are two possible size options:
- 'm': medium size
- 'l': large size

The default value is 'm'.

methods.name: updateStyles
methods.docs: Use this method to force the component to update its styles. It can be useful when the select is reset (with a placeholder).

props.name: href
props.docs:
Attributes mapped to a <a> tag.

Don't forget to specify [routerLink] if using in conjuction with angular router.

props.name: text
props.docs: This attribute specify the text of the item.

components.docs:
The progress-bar component is a horizontal bar that indicates the current completion of a task.

## Accessibility guidelines 
> Aria attributes and how to display the progress-bar depend on the use case in your application :
>  
> - **Case 1 : decorative**  
> If the progress-bar is used as a decoration _(if removed, the user doesn't lose any relevant information)_ or in the
> context of another component _(such as progress-bar in a card, stepper, ...)_ => **you don't need to show the label nor add an aria-label**.
> 
> - **Case 2 : informative**  
> If the progress-bar is used to convey important information _(e.g., form completion status, dashboard KPI)_, you need to :
>   - **Provide a visible label** that describes the purpose of the progress-bar.
>   - **Set the `showLabel` property to `true`** to show the percentage above the progress-bar.
>   - Optionally, use aria-label to provide an accessible name if a visible label is not present.

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-progress-bar-border-radius - Border radius

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-progress-bar-border-radius-small - Border radius for size small

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-progress-bar-animation-duration - Animation duration

props.name: showLabel
props.docs: Whether it displays a label indicating the percentage of progress above the bar.

props.name: size
props.docs:
Specify the size of the progress bar.  
m = default, s = smaller

props.name: value
props.docs:
The actual value of the progress.
Ranging from 0 to 100.

components.docs: The progress-radial component is a circular progress bar that indicates the current completion of a task.

props.name: showLabel
props.docs: Whether the component should display the % label inside

props.name: size
props.docs: The size of the progress radial (in px)

props.name: value
props.docs: The value of the progress radial. Prefer values between 0 and 100.

props.name: checked
props.docs: If `true`, the radio is selected.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the radio.

props.name: name
props.docs: Giving every radio button the same name is mandatory to group them

events.docs: Emitted when the value has changed.

components.docs:
The select component (also named combobox) is a form component that allows users to select one or more options
from a list.
Use it with several slotted `wcs-select-option` inside.

docsTags.name: slot
docsTags.text: filter-no-result Contains the customizable "No result found" div (autocomplete mode only).

props.name: autocomplete
props.docs: If `true`, the select acts as an autocomplete field to filter your results.

props.name: chips
props.docs: If `true`, selected items are shown in chips mode.

props.name: compareWith
props.docs: Function used to compare options, default : deep comparison.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the select.

props.name: filterFn
props.docs:
Customizable sort function to change the comparison of values. If not provided, uses the default behavior :
`option.textContent.toLowerCase().startsWith(filter.toLowerCase())`

props.name: multiple
props.docs: If `true`, the user can select multiple values at once.

props.name: name
props.docs: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

props.name: placeholder
props.docs: The text to display when the select is empty.

props.name: size
props.docs: Specify the size (height) of the select.

props.name: value
props.docs: The currently selected value.

events.docs: Emitted when the select loses focus.
Emitted when the value has changed.
Emitted when the autocomplete filter has changed.
Emitted when the select has focus.

slots.name: filter-no-result Contains the customizable "No result found" div (autocomplete mode only).

components.docs: The select option is a subcomponent of `wcs-select` that represents a single option in a select list.

props.name: chipBackgroundColor
props.docs: Chip's background color.

props.name: chipColor
props.docs: Chip's displayed text color.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether this option can be selected.

props.name: selected
props.docs: Whether this option is selected.

props.name: value
props.docs: The option value, not what's displayed, use inner text instead.

components.docs: Use a skeleton circle as a placeholder round images, illustrations or components

props.name: animation
props.docs: Specifies the animation of the skeleton

props.name: radius
props.docs: Specifies the radius of the circle in px

components.docs: Use a skeleton rectangle as a placeholder for large images or square-shaped components

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-skeleton-border-radius - Controls the border-radius of the 'rounded' skeleton rectangle (default 0.5rem)

props.name: animation
props.docs: Specifies the animation of the skeleton

props.name: height
props.docs: Specifies the height of the skeleton (can be any valid CSS value)

props.name: rounded
props.docs: Adds a border radius on the skeleton if true

props.name: width
props.docs: Specifies the width of the skeleton (can be any valid CSS value)

components.docs: Use a skeleton text as a placeholder for titles or paragraphs.

props.name: animation
props.docs: Specifies the animation of the skeleton

props.name: height
props.docs: Specifies the line height of the text skeleton

props.name: mode
props.docs:
Indicates the spinner display mode.
Accepted values: `border` or `growing`

props.name: checked
props.docs: If `true`, the switch is selected.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Specify wether the switch is disabled or not.

props.name: labelAlignment
props.docs: Specifie the alignment of the switch with the label content

events.docs: Emitted when the checked property has changed.

components.docs:
Tab content component.
Use this component to specify the content of a component.

props.name: header
props.docs: The header you want to be displayed for this tab.

props.name: itemKey
props.docs: The id of the tab. It should be unique.

events.docs: Do not use, meant for internal use only.

components.docs:
Tabs component to switch between tab content.
Use in conjuction with `wcs-tab`.

docsTags.name: example
docsTags.text:
```html
<wcs-tabs>
   <wcs-tab header="One">The content !</wcs-tab>
   <wcs-tab header="Two">More content !</wcs-tab>
</wcs-tabs>
```

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-tabs-width - Width of each tab

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-tabs-padding-horizontal - Width of each tab

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-tabs-padding-vertical - Vertical padding

props.name: align
props.docs: Tab headers alignment.

props.name: description
props.docs: Description is used to provide aria-label for the tabs container which has `role="tablist"`.

props.name: gutter
props.docs: Determines if tabs header should have a border at the bottom

props.name: headersOnly
props.docs:
Whether to skip rendering the tabpanel with the content of the selected tab. Use this prop if you plan to
separately render the tab content.

props.name: selectedIndex
props.docs:
Current selected tab index.
Starts at 0.

events.docs: Emitted when the selected tab change.

components.docs:
Mainly inspired from Ionic Textarea Component.

## Accessibility guidelines 
> `wcs-textarea` is a wrapper around the native textarea element which is located inside its shadow DOM. All the
> **aria attributes** you set on `wcs-textarea` are passed to the **native textarea** element **during the first render of the component**.
> If you need to use them as you would with a native textarea, you can do so.

> If you need to **dynamically change the aria attributes after the first render**, you can use the `setAriaAttribute`
> JS method of `wcs-textarea` :

> ```javascript
> const wcsTextarea = document.querySelector('wcs-textarea');
> await wcsTextarea.setAriaAttribute('aria-label', 'new label');
> ```

> If you use wcs-textarea outside a wcs-form-field, you have to manage the label and the error message yourself.
> You can use the `aria-label` attribute to provide a label for screen readers but adds no visual label.

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-textarea-max-height - Max height of the text area component

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-textarea-padding-left - Padding left of the text area. Take in consideration the transparent border of 2px around the textarea.

docsTags.name: cssprop
docsTags.text: --wcs-textarea-padding-right - Padding right of the text area. Take in consideration the transparent border of 2px around the textarea.

props.name: autoGrow
props.docs: If `true`, the element height will increase based on the value.

props.name: autocapitalize
props.docs: Indicates whether and how the text value should be automatically capitalized as it is entered/edited by the user.

props.name: autofocus
props.docs: This Boolean attribute lets you specify that a form control should have input focus when the page loads.

props.name: clearOnEdit
props.docs: If `true`, the value will be cleared after focus upon edit. Defaults to `true` when `type` is `"password"`, `false` for all other types.

props.name: cols
props.docs:
The visible width of the text control, in average character widths. If it is specified, it must be a positive integer.  
Note : at the moment, modifying the width is only possible if you add some custom CSS to the component,
for example by overriding the `width` CSS property. See the Resize section for an example on how to do it.

props.name: debounce
props.docs:
Set the amount of time, in milliseconds, to wait to trigger the `wcsInput` event after each keystroke.
This also impacts form bindings such as `ngModel` or `v-model`.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the textarea.

props.name: enterkeyhint
props.docs: A hint to the browser for which enter key to display.

props.name: icon
props.docs: Name of the material icon to add to the input

props.name: inputmode
props.docs: A hint to the browser for which keyboard to display.

props.name: maxlength
props.docs: If the value of the type attribute is `text`, `email`, `search`, `password`, `tel`, or `url`, this attribute specifies the maximum number of characters that the user can enter.

props.name: minlength
props.docs: If the value of the type attribute is `text`, `email`, `search`, `password`, `tel`, or `url`, this attribute specifies the minimum number of characters that the user can enter.

props.name: name
props.docs: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

props.name: placeholder
props.docs: Instructional text that shows before the input has a value.

props.name: readonly
props.docs: If `true`, the user cannot modify the value.

props.name: required
props.docs: If `true`, the user must fill in a value before submitting a form.

props.name: resize
props.docs:
Indicates how the textarea should be resizable.  
Note : at the moment horizontal resizing is only possible if you add custom CSS to the component,
see the Resize section for an example.

props.name: rows
props.docs: The number of visible text lines for the control.

props.name: spellcheck
props.docs: If `true`, the element will have its spelling and grammar checked.

props.name: state
props.docs: Specifies the state of the input. By default the input is in an initial state but you can set it to 'error' state if the data given by the user is not valid.

props.name: value
props.docs: The value of the textarea.

props.name: wrap
props.docs: Indicates how the control wraps text.

methods.name: fitContent
methods.docs: This method make the textarea automatically adopt the size of the content without a scroll bar

methods.name: getInputElement
methods.docs: Returns the native `<textarea>` element used under the hood.

methods.name: setFocus

docsTags.name: deprecated
docsTags.text:
use the native focus method instead  
Sets focus on the native `textarea` in `wcs-textarea`.

methods.deprecation:
use the native focus method instead  
Sets focus on the native `textarea` in `wcs-textarea`.

events.docs: Emitted when the input loses focus.
Emitted when the input value has changed.- See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/change
Emitted when the input has focus.
Emitted when a keyboard input occurred. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/input

components.docs:
Tooltips are used to provide additional information for features available on the website. These can improve the user
experience or simply show additional information. Tooltips appear when the user rolls over or clicks on them
(for longer content).

Note that this component is based on the Tippy.js library : https://atomiks.github.io/tippyjs/

props.name: appendTo
props.docs:
The element to append the tooltip to. Default behaviour is `() => document.body`. If interactive: true,
the default behavior is appendTo: "parent"

See: https://atomiks.github.io/tippyjs/v6/all-props/#appendto

props.name: content
props.docs:
You can use this property instead of the slot API to affect content in the tooltip.

This makes it easier to manage the update if the tooltip contains elements that are not mutated when their
content changes. Indeed, if the slot is used, the tooltip is updated only if the structure of the slotted DOM
changes (the DOM must be mutated).

The two APIs are not mutually exclusive, if both are filled in (the prop + the slot) the rendering will first
display the content of this property and then the slotted elements.

props.name: delay
props.docs:
Delay in ms once a trigger event is fired before the tooltip shows or hides.

You can provide an array with two values to define a different duration for show and hide.

`[showDelay, hideDelay]`

Use null to use default value.

props.name: duration
props.docs: Duration in ms of the transition animation.

props.name: for
props.docs:
The **id** of the element the tooltip's going to describe.

This property cannot be modified after initialization.

docsTags.name: example
docsTags.text: ```html Some content A tooltip! ```

props.name: interactive
props.docs:
Determines if the tooltip has interactive content inside of it, so that it can be hovered over and clicked inside
without hiding.

props.name: maxWidth
props.docs:
Specifies the maximum width of the tooltip. Useful to prevent it from being too horizontally wide to read.

If the viewport's width is smaller than maxWidth, core CSS ensures the tippy remains smaller than the screen.

props.name: position
props.docs: Where the tooltip is going to show relative to the element it's describing.

props.name: theme
props.docs:
Allows you to change the theme used by tippy.

The WCS theme is used by default and uses the WCS CSS variables.

You can create a theme by following this documentation and choosing a custom name :
https://atomiks.github.io/tippyjs/v6/themes/

props.name: trigger
props.docs:
Determines the events that cause the tooltip to show. Multiple event names are separated by spaces.

See: https://atomiks.github.io/tippyjs/v6/all-props/#trigger

methods.name: disable
methods.docs: Temporarily prevent the tooltip from showing or hiding
